EtherCAT Master

EtherCAT Master corresponds to a network adaptor which has been configured to operate as an EtherCAT master in Measurement and Automation Explorer (MAX). Make sure the Master ID matches the ID configured in MAX.

Cyclic Data Bandwidth (%) is the percent of the scan engine period dedicated to completing the scan. You can usually leave this at the default value (40), but if you increase the scan engine rate or have a large amount of I/O on the EtherCAT master, you may need to increase this value. Note that increasing this value may give VeriStand less time to complete other tasks (process I/O, run models, etc...).

What do you want to do?

Add an NI 914x EtherCAT Slave

To add an NI 914x EtherCAT Slave, click the Add NI 914x EtherCAT Slave button. You also can right-click the EtherCAT Master in the configuration tree and select Add NI 914x EtherCAT Slave from the shortcut menu. This will create an NI 914x EtherCAT Slave in the next available position.

Manage 3rd-Party EtherCAT Slaves

Before you can add a 3rd-Party EtherCAT slave, you must import the Electronic Slave Information (ESI) file. To import the ESI file, click the Manage 3rd-Party ECAT Slaves button. You also can right-click the EtherCAT Master in the configuration tree and select Manage 3rd-Party ECAT Slaves from the shortcut menu.

To add a 3rd-Party EtherCAT slave, go to the Scan Engine and EtherCAT section in the configuration-tree and click the Auto-Detect Modules button. You also can right-click Scan Engine and EtherCAT in the configuration tree and select Auto-Detect Modules from the shortcut menu. This will find all Local Chassis, EtherCAT masters, slaves, and modules currently connected to your system, and add them to your System Definition.
